data.title: Epiphyseal Cortical Irregularity
data.content:
A normal anatomical variation characterized by irregularity and fragmentation in the medial aspect of the distal femoral epiphysis, commonly seen in pediatric X-rays. It must be distinguished from pathological conditions like osteomyelitis or tumors.

 

Causes and Predisposing Factors

  • Developmental Variation: Physiological irregularity during skeletal growth in children.
  • Age Factor: Typically observed in young children, reflecting the normal maturation of the epiphysis.
  • Mechanical Stress: Repeated stress on the knee joint can contribute to this appearance.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy

  • Distal Femur: The medial portion of the distal femoral epiphysis shows irregular contour with subtle fragmentation.
  • Cartilage and Bone Growth Centers: In children, these areas are dynamic and prone to appearance changes on imaging.

 

Mechanism of Disease

  • Physiological Growth: Occurs as a result of normal endochondral ossification processes.
  • Differentiation from Pathology: Fragmentation or irregularity is part of natural bone development and does not signify an inflammatory or neoplastic process.

 

Clinical Manifestations

  • Symptoms:
    • Mild knee or leg pain, often transient.
    • No significant systemic signs like fever or inflammation that suggest pathology.

 

Imaging Role

  1. Preliminary Evaluation:
    • Helps confirm the finding and differentiate it from diseases like osteomyelitis or tumors.
    • Best visualized on AP projection X-rays.
  2. Complication Assessment:
    • Unlikely, but imaging ensures no additional pathology is present.
  3. Surveillance and Follow-Up:
    • Generally unnecessary unless symptoms persist or worsen.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities

  • X-ray (Primary Modality):
    • AP view: Mild irregularity and fragmentation of the medial distal femoral epiphysis.
    • No surrounding soft tissue swelling or periosteal reaction, differentiating it from infections or malignancies.
  • MRI/CT (Rarely Indicated):
    • May show normal epiphyseal cartilage without abnormalities.

 

Complications

  • None expected as this represents a normal anatomical variation.

 

Management

  • Observation: No treatment is necessary; reassurance to caregivers about the benign nature is sufficient.

 

Alternative Diagnoses

  • Osteomyelitis: Typically associated with fever, swelling, and systemic signs.
  • Neoplastic Lesions: Often show destructive bone changes or periosteal reactions.
  • Fractures: Present with acute history of trauma and pain localized to the area.

 

Bibliography

  1. Seo SG, et al. (2014). Incidental findings on knee radiographs in children and adolescents. Clinics in Orthopedic Surgery, 6(3), 305-311. DOI: 10.4055/cios.2014.6.3.305.
  2. Pediatric Orthopedic Textbooks and Radiology Atlases.

data.title: Macaroni sign
data.content:
The Doppler image provided shows a characteristic "macaroni sign," which is highly suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. The color Doppler imaging demonstrates a concentric, homogeneous circumferential thickening of the arterial wall with increased vascular flow indicating inflammation. This specific "macaroni sign" is seen on transverse section and is a notable feature in Takayasu arteritis, distinguishing it from atherosclerosis, which typically appears non-homogeneous, calcified, and with irregular walls.

Takayasu Arteritis

Introduction
Takayasu arteritis (TAK), also known as idiopathic medial aortopathy or "pulseless disease," is a granulomatous large vessel vasculitis affecting the aorta and its major branches.

Etiology/Risk Factors
Likely immune-mediated; associated with a higher prevalence in Asian women aged 15-30.

Pathophysiology

TAK involves segmental, granulomatous inflammation of the aorta and its branches, leading to stenosis, thrombosis, and aneurysmal formations. The inflammation damages the vessel wall, resulting in vascular narrowing, ischemia, and potential occlusion of blood flow.

Clinical Features

  1. Systemic symptoms: Malaise, fever, weight loss
  2. Vascular symptoms: Limb claudication, reduced or absent peripheral pulses
  3. Hypertension due to renovascular involvement
  4. Limb ischemia
  5. Aortic regurgitation (due to aortic root involvement)

Classification

Based on the location of vascular involvement:

  1. Type I - Aortic arch branches
  2. Type IIa - Ascending aorta and/or arch without branches
  3. Type IIb - Descending thoracic aorta with or without aortic arch
  4. Type III - Thoracic and abdominal aorta
  5. Type IV - Abdominal aorta and/or renal arteries
  6. Type V - Generalized involvement of all aortic segments

Staging

  1. Pre-pulseless phase: Systemic symptoms without pulse abnormalities
  2. Pulseless phase: Characterized by ischemic symptoms and absence of pulses

Imaging Features

Ultrasound

  • Concentric, homogeneous thickening of arterial walls, termed the "macaroni sign"
  • Vascular occlusion due to intimal thickening or thrombus
  • Reduced pulsatility
  • Possible aneurysmal dilations

CT/MRI

  • Wall thickening and enhancement in active phase
  • Aortic valve stenosis or regurgitation
  • Occlusion or narrowing of major branches
  • Aneurysmal or pseudoaneurysmal formations
  • "Peripheral pruning" in pulmonary arteries

CT Coronary Angiography

  • Coronary artery stenosis, especially at the ostia
  • Coronary artery aneurysms
  • "String of pearls sign" indicating sequential aneurysms and stenoses

Complications

Hypertension, aortic regurgitation, aneurysm rupture, myocardial infarction, and limb ischemia

Treatment

  1. Medical: Corticosteroids for initial treatment; immunosuppressive agents (methotrexate, azathioprine) as steroid-sparing options
  2. Surgical/Interventional: Angioplasty, stent placement, and bypass surgery once inflammation is controlled

Differential Diagnosis

  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia

A Glimpse of the History

In 1908, a Japanese ophthalmologist named Dr. Mikito Takayasu was conducting a routine eye exam when he noticed something peculiar—a “winding” pattern of blood vessels on a young woman’s retina. Now, he might have thought he was seeing things after a long day, but this observation turned out to be the beginning of something big. News of his discovery spread, and soon, other doctors noticed similar findings in patients with weak pulses in their limbs. Fast forward a bit, and Takayasu’s “lucky find” is now a well-known vascular disease! If Dr. Takayasu had been an artist, we might have been calling this the “spiral art disease” instead.

References

  1. Wolfgang Dähnert. Radiology Review Manual. (2011)
  2. Sueyoshi E, Sakamoto I, Uetani M. MRI of Takayasu's arteritis. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2006
  3. Gotway MB, Araoz PA, Macedo TA. Imaging findings in Takayasu's arteritis. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2005

data.title: Omental caking
data.content:
The CT scan image depicts an "omental cake" appearance, characterized by diffuse infiltration of the omental fat with soft-tissue density, forming a contiguous mass-like pattern resembling the top of a cake. This finding is suggestive of peritoneal carcinomatosis but requires further clinical correlation and investigation.

Introduction
Omental cake refers to the replacement or infiltration of omental fat by soft tissue, often due to malignancy, giving a characteristic cake-like appearance on imaging.

Etiology/Risk Factors
Commonly associated with metastases from ovarian, gastric, or colon cancers.

Pathophysiology
Malignant cells spread via peritoneal surfaces, implanting and proliferating within the omentum, leading to omental thickening and infiltration by tumor cells. This results in the replacement of normal fat with soft-tissue density, often accompanied by ascites.

Clinical Features

  • Abdominal pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Weight loss
  • Early satiety
  • Ascites

Imaging Features

CT Scan

  • Thickened, infiltrative soft-tissue density in the omental region.
  • Mass-like appearance replacing normal omental fat.
  • Often accompanied by malignant ascites.
  • Peritoneal nodularity may be present.

MRI

  • Hypointense signal on T1-weighted images due to soft-tissue density replacing fat.
  • Variable signal intensity on T2, depending on the composition (e.g., necrotic or fibrotic areas).
  • Enhanced after gadolinium administration, helping to delineate tumor margins.

Ultrasound

  • Hyperechoic or complex echogenic areas within the omentum.
  • Associated ascites with septations or debris may be observed.
  • May show free-floating omental masses in fluid-filled spaces.

PET-CT

  • Increased FDG uptake in metabolically active malignant omental tissue.
  • Useful for detecting the extent and distribution of peritoneal metastasis.

Complications

  • Bowel obstruction due to encasement.
  • Malignant ascites leading to abdominal distension.
  • Potential for extensive spread within the peritoneal cavity.

Treatment

  • Chemotherapy: Primary treatment, especially in ovarian and gastrointestinal malignancies.
  • Surgery: Debulking surgery may be considered for symptom relief.
  • Targeted Therapy: Used depending on the primary cancer type and molecular markers.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Tuberculous peritonitis (granulomatous inflammation)
  • Lymphoma (usually with significant lymphadenopathy)
  • Malignant peritoneal mesothelioma (diffuse peritoneal thickening)
  • Pseudomyxoma peritonei (mucinous ascites with scalloping of surfaces)

References

  1. Radiopaedia.org on Omental Cake - Imaging Findings and Differential Diagnoses
  2. Textbook of Radiology and Imaging - Abdominal Imaging Section
  3. AJR American Journal of Roentgenology - Peritoneal and Omental Diseases

data.title: Testicular Epidermoid
data.content:
• The ultrasound image reveals a well-defined testicular lesion displaying an "onion skin" or "whorled" appearance.
  • This pattern is characterized by concentric alternating layers of hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings, typical of a testicular epidermoid cyst (TEC).
  • The layered appearance results from keratinized material within the cyst, aiding in differentiating TEC from malignant testicular lesions.

Introduction

  • Testicular epidermoid cysts (TECs) are benign, keratin-filled cystic lesions in the testis, recognized for their characteristic layered appearance.

Etiology/Risk Factors

  • TECs arise from squamous epithelial cells within the testis; exact cause unknown and often appear without known risk factors.

Relevant Radiological Anatomy

  • Located within the testicular parenchyma, the concentric layers in TECs are due to keratin deposits within the cyst.

Pathophysiology

  • TECs form when squamous cells in the testis produce keratin, which accumulates over time, creating the layered, lamellated structure characteristic of these cysts.

Clinical Features

  1. Painless, non-tender testicular mass.
  2. Typically small (1-3 cm).
  3. Asymptomatic in most cases.
  4. May be incidentally discovered on imaging.
  5. Usually well-circumscribed on palpation.

Imaging Features

  • Ultrasound:

    • Well-circumscribed, avascular intratesticular lesion.
    • Lamellated "onion skin" appearance with alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings.
    • May exhibit a target appearance, with a central hyperechoic core and surrounding hypoechoic halo.

  • MRI:

    • T1-weighted: Variable signal intensity, often with alternating high and low signal bands.
    • T2-weighted: Low-intensity rim with alternating signal rings.
    • T1 C+ (Gadolinium): Typically no enhancement due to lack of vascularity.

Complications

  • Rare, but misdiagnosis as malignancy could lead to unnecessary orchiectomy.

Treatment

  • Testis-sparing enucleation, with intraoperative frozen section for confirmation of benign pathology.

Differential Diagnosis

  1. Testicular germ cell tumor (e.g., seminoma) – typically vascular.
  2. Testicular teratoma – heterogeneous appearance with mixed tissue elements.
  3. Tunica albuginea cyst – anechoic, lacks layered appearance.
  4. Focal granulomatous disease – variable echogenicity.
  5. Testicular hemorrhage – echogenicity depends on stage of hemorrhage.

A Glimpse of the History

  • Imagine it's 1942. Amidst the chaos of World War II, two pathologists, Dockerty and Priestly, examine an unusual testicular specimen with a peculiar layered pattern under the microscope. They observe something that resembles an onion slice, raising questions about its nature—tumor or benign anomaly? After careful study, they conclude it's a harmless testicular epidermoid cyst, non-threatening but unique in structure. This discovery saves countless testes from unnecessary surgeries and secures TEC's place in the annals of benign pathology. Dockerty and Priestly’s observation reshaped testicular lesion management, highlighting the importance of precise diagnosis.

References

  1. Loya AG, Said JW, Grant EG. Epidermoid cyst of the testis: radiologic-pathologic correlation. Radiographics. 2004;24 Suppl 1 : S243-6.
  2. Bennett GL, Garcia RA. Benign intratesticular dermoid cyst: sonographic findings. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2002;179 (5): 1315-7.
  3. Cho JH, Chang JC, Park BH et-al. Sonographic and MR imaging findings of testicular epidermoid cysts. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2002;178 (3): 743-8.

data.title: IHBRD
data.content:
The ultrasound image shows intrahepatic bile duct dilatation (IHBRD), which can be assessed by looking for anechoic (dark) tubular structures within the liver that are larger than normal, appearing adjacent to the portal vein branches. 

 

Overview

  • Bile duct dilatation refers to the enlargement of the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts beyond their normal size.
  • Commonly associated with obstruction, leading to impaired bile flow and potential complications like jaundice.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors

  • Obstructions: Most frequently due to choledocholithiasis or strictures.
  • Neoplasms: Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma or pancreatic head masses.
  • Other Factors: Biliary cysts, post-surgical changes, or chronic opioid use.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy

  • Intrahepatic Ducts: Normally <2 mm in diameter; considered dilated if >40% of the adjacent portal vein diameter.
  • Extrahepatic Ducts: Includes the common hepatic and common bile ducts, with dilatation defined as >6 mm or >10 mm post-cholecystectomy.

 

Mechanism of Disease

  • Increased Pressure: Obstruction elevates intra-biliary pressure, causing upstream dilatation.
  • Duct Wall Changes: Prolonged obstruction can lead to loss of duct wall elasticity or structural changes.

 

Clinical Manifestations

  • Right Upper Quadrant Pain: Common presentation.
  • Jaundice: Results from biliary stasis and impaired bile excretion.
  • Systemic Signs: May include fever if accompanied by cholangitis.

 

Imaging Role

  • Preliminary Evaluation:
    • Ultrasound: Primary modality; harmonic imaging improves visualization.
  • Complication Assessment:
    • Color Doppler: Differentiates dilated bile ducts from vascular structures.
  • Surveillance: Essential for monitoring post-treatment changes or potential recurrence.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities

  • Ultrasound: Shows dilated, anechoic tubular structures within the liver.
  • CT/MRI: Useful for identifying the cause of obstruction, delineating adjacent structures.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive technique that provides clear images of the biliary system.

 

Complications

  • Cholangitis: Infection due to stagnant bile.
  • Secondary Biliary Cirrhosis: Result of chronic obstruction.
  • Biliary Peritonitis: Possible with severe obstruction or rupture.

 

Management

  • Initial Approach: Address underlying causes, such as ERCP for stone removal or stent placement.

 

Alternative Diagnoses

  • Portal Vein Anomalies: May mimic bile duct dilation on imaging.
  • Hepatic Cysts/Hemangiomas: Differentiated by imaging characteristics.

 

 

Bibliography

  1. Zahedi-Nejad N., et al. (2010). Analysis of CBD diameters in opium-addicted men. Polish Journal of Radiology, 75(3): 20-4.
  2. Park SM, et al. (2012). Study on post-cholecystectomy common bile duct dilation. Journal of the Korean Surgical Society, 83(2): 97-101.

data.title: Yin-Yang sign
data.content:
The Doppler ultrasound image shows a Yin-Yang sign, demonstrating bidirectional blood flow within an aneurysm, creating a distinct swirling pattern. This pattern is indicative of turbulent blood flow within either a true or false aneurysm, appearing as two contrasting areas of blood flow moving in opposite directions within the same cavity.

 

Overview

  • Definition: The Yin-Yang sign, also known as the "Pepsi sign," is a Doppler ultrasound finding indicative of bidirectional blood flow within an aneurysm, particularly helpful in identifying both true and pseudoaneurysms.

 

Causes and Predisposing Factors

  • True Aneurysms: Result from full-thickness arterial wall weakening, often due to chronic conditions like atherosclerosis.
  • False Aneurysms (Pseudoaneurysms): Often caused by trauma or procedural injury, where a tear in the vessel wall allows blood to collect outside the vessel, creating a pulsatile hematoma.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy

  • Common Sites: Most commonly seen in peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral artery) but may occur in any vessel, including cerebral, abdominal, or thoracic arteries.

 

Mechanism of Disease

  • True Aneurysm: Involves all three vessel wall layers and maintains a continuous blood flow within the dilated section of the vessel.
  • False Aneurysm: Blood flows between vessel wall layers or into the surrounding tissue, leading to turbulent, bidirectional flow.

 

Clinical Manifestations

  • Symptoms: Can include localized pain, swelling, a palpable pulsatile mass, and potential for distal ischemic symptoms.
  • Risk of Rupture: Both types, especially larger aneurysms, carry risks of rupture and hemorrhage.

 

Classification

  • True Aneurysm: Involves the entire vessel wall.
  • False Aneurysm (Pseudoaneurysm): Results from an incomplete vessel wall injury, often with an external collection of blood.

 

Imaging Role

  1. Preliminary Evaluation:
    • Confirm presence of aneurysm and differentiate between true and pseudoaneurysm.
  2. Complication Assessment:
    • Identify thrombus, vessel wall integrity, and risk factors for potential rupture.
  3. Surveillance and Follow-Up:
    • Monitor aneurysm growth and assess stability or regression post-intervention.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities

  • Doppler Ultrasound: Shows the classic Yin-Yang sign, with bidirectional flow patterns due to blood swirling within the aneurysm cavity.
  • CT Angiography: No exact correlate for the Yin-Yang sign; however, contrast enhancement may show the patent lumen, with reduced attenuation in low-flow or thrombosed regions.

 

Complications

  • Potential for Thrombosis: May obstruct blood flow to distal regions.
  • Rupture: Larger aneurysms are at a higher risk of rupture, which can lead to hemorrhage and other life-threatening complications.

 

Management 

  • Treatment: Depending on the size and risk, options include conservative management, endovascular intervention, or surgical repair.

 

Alternative Diagnosis

  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Arteriovenous malformations, especially if turbulent flow is present.
    • Vascular tumors or hematomas with complex flow patterns.

 

Historical Insights

  • Origins: Named after the Yin-Yang symbol, representing dualism and interdependent opposites in Chinese philosophy.
  • Pepsi® Logo Similarity: The swirling flow pattern also resembles the logo for Pepsi®, contributing to its nickname, the "Pepsi sign."

 

Bibliography

  1. Lupattelli T. "The yin-yang sign." Radiology. 2006;238 (3): 1070-1.
  2. Saad NE, et al. "Pseudoaneurysms and minimally invasive management." Radiographics. 2005;25 Suppl 1: S173-89.

data.title: Cirsoid aneurysm
data.content:
Overview

  • Cirsoid aneurysm, a rare type of arteriovenous malformation (AVM), typically affects the scalp or extremities. It involves abnormal direct arteriovenous connections without an intervening capillary network, leading to a pulsatile vascular mass.

Cause and Predisposing Factors

  • Congenital Predisposition: Mostly congenital in nature.
  • Trauma: Rare cases occur post-trauma, where arteriovenous connections form due to injury.

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy

  • Primary Arterial Supply: Usually involves the superficial temporal artery, occasionally with contributions from the occipital artery.
  • Drainage Pathway: Direct drainage into superficial scalp veins, creating a characteristic vascular mass.

Mechanism of Disease

  • Pathophysiology: Direct arteriovenous shunting bypasses capillary networks, leading to high-flow arteriovenous connections. This high-pressure blood flow in veins results in their dilation and pulsatility, manifesting as a palpable and sometimes visible mass on the scalp.

Clinical Manifestations

  • Primary Symptoms: Slow-growing, pulsatile scalp mass.
  • Additional Symptoms: Tinnitus, local pain, headache, and potential cosmetic disfigurement.
  • Complications: Possible ulceration or hemorrhage in severe cases.

Classification

  • Based on Etiology:
    • Congenital Cirsoid Aneurysms
    • Post-traumatic Cirsoid Aneurysms

Imaging Role

  • Preliminary Evaluation:
    • Goal: Confirm the presence of arteriovenous connections and delineate the extent.
    • Preferred Modality: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) for detailed vascular mapping.
  • Complication Assessment:
    • Purpose: Detect secondary complications such as venous thrombosis, hemorrhage, or skin ulceration.
    • Additional Modalities: MRI with contrast or CT angiography.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up:
    • Objective: Monitor for therapeutic success, recurrence, or any post-treatment complications.
    • Interval Imaging: Typically, follow-up with MRI or DSA as per the clinical need.

Imaging Characteristics

  • Ultrasound: Non-invasive evaluation; detects pulsatile flow and abnormal vessel morphology.
  • MRI: Shows flow voids in superficial vessels, often indicative of high-flow AVMs.
  • CT Angiography: Visualizes vascular anatomy and aids in preoperative planning.
  • DSA: Gold standard for detailed vascular anatomy and real-time assessment of arteriovenous shunting.

Complications

  • Hemorrhage: Secondary to fragile vessels, particularly with trauma.
  • Cosmetic Deformity: Enlarging vascular masses may cause disfigurement.
  • Ulceration and Bleeding: Increased risk with thinning scalp over the lesion.

Management

  • Primary Options:
    • Endovascular Occlusion
    • Surgical Resection
    • Sclerotherapy

Differential Diagnosis

  1. Soft Tissue Venous Malformation: Often mistaken due to similar appearance.
  2. Dural Arteriovenous Fistula: Can mimic cirsoid aneurysms if it drains transosseously.
  3. Sinus Pericranii: Involves extracranial veins with direct connection to intracranial sinuses.

A Glimpse of History

  • Imagine the year is 1833, and a doctor named Brecht comes across a patient with a pulsating scalp. "Why is your head doing the cha-cha?" he wonders, and thus, the term "cirsoid aneurysm" is born. Fast forward, and here we are, still trying to get these high-flow AVMs under control with a mix of surgery and modern-day magic called endovascular occlusion. A story from scalp cha-cha to endovascular finesse!

Bibliography

  1. Tauro LF, Suhith G, Shetty P et al., Cirsoid aneurysm of the scalp, Journal of Neurosciences in Rural Practice, 2012; 3(1): 95-6.
  2. Corr PD., Cirsoid aneurysm of the scalp, Singapore Medical Journal, 2007; 48(10): e268-9.
  3. Arora AM, Puri SKM, Upreti LM., Brain Imaging: Case Review Series, Jaypee Brothers Medical Pub, 2011.

data.title: Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS)
data.content:
The lateral X-ray of a patient with characteristic findings of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS). This includes evidence of scoliosis, short stature, and thoracolumbar kyphosis. Additionally, the bullet-shaped vertebrae are visible in the X-ray, which is a hallmark sign seen in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis, particularly in Hurler syndrome.

 

Overview:

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of rare hereditary lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the abnormal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (mucopolysaccharides) due to deficiencies in enzymes responsible for their degradation. This results in progressive multisystem involvement, including skeletal, cardiac, respiratory, and neurological manifestations.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Genetic inheritance: Most MPS types are autosomal recessive, except MPS II (Hunter syndrome), which is X-linked.
  • Enzyme deficiencies: Specific enzyme deficiencies, such as alpha-L-iduronidase in Hurler syndrome, lead to impaired breakdown of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), leading to their accumulation in various tissues.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Spine: The vertebrae often show bullet-shaped deformities, kyphosis, and scoliosis.
  • Skeleton: Bone deformities, joint contractures, and dysostosis multiplex are common radiological findings.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

Due to enzyme deficiencies, mucopolysaccharides accumulate within the lysosomes of various tissues, disrupting normal cellular function. This leads to progressive tissue and organ dysfunction, including skeletal deformities, organomegaly, and neurological impairment.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Skeletal abnormalities: Dysostosis multiplex (including bullet-shaped vertebrae, scoliosis, kyphosis).
  • Facial features: Coarse facies, thickened skin.
  • Respiratory issues: Airway obstruction and recurrent respiratory infections.
  • Cardiac involvement: Valvular disease and cardiomyopathy.
  • Neurological impairment: Developmental delay and cognitive decline, particularly in severe forms such as Hurler syndrome (MPS-IH).


 

Classification:

  • MPS I: Hurler syndrome (most severe), Scheie syndrome (milder).
  • MPS II: Hunter syndrome.
  • MPS III: Sanfilippo syndrome.
  • MPS IV: Morquio syndrome.
  • MPS VI: Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS VII: Sly syndrome.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Identification of skeletal abnormalities like bullet-shaped vertebrae and kyphosis, helping to suggest a diagnosis.
  • Complication Assessment: Monitoring of progressive changes, including joint stiffness, spinal deformities, and airway obstruction.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Monitoring disease progression and response to enzyme replacement therapies or other treatments.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • X-ray:
    • Spinal deformities: Bullet-shaped vertebrae, kyphosis, scoliosis.
    • Bone changes: Widened ribs, shortened long bones, and metaphyseal flaring.
  • MRI:
    • Neurological involvement: Brain atrophy, enlarged perivascular spaces, and white matter changes.
  • CT:
    • Useful for evaluating organ involvement, especially airway and cardiac abnormalities.

 

Complications:

  • Neurological impairment: Progressive mental decline, particularly in severe MPS types.
  • Respiratory compromise: Airway obstruction and sleep apnea.
  • Cardiac involvement: Heart valve dysfunction, leading to heart failure.
  • Orthopedic issues: Joint contractures, progressive skeletal deformities, and limited mobility.

 

Management:

Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) and supportive care aimed at alleviating symptoms, slowing disease progression, and improving quality of life.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Achondroplasia: Short stature with spinal deformities but no enzyme deficiency.
  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia: Another form of skeletal dysplasia causing spinal abnormalities but without the systemic involvement of MPS.
  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy: A lysosomal storage disorder affecting the nervous system rather than the skeleton.

 

 

A Glimpse of History:

Mucopolysaccharidoses were first described in the early 20th century, with the discovery of Hurler syndrome by Gertrud Hurler in 1919. The development of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) has been a significant advancement in the treatment of these disorders, offering hope for improving quality of life and slowing disease progression.

 

Bibliography:

  2. Berquist TH. Musculoskeletal imaging companion. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. 2007.
  3. Reichert R, Campos LG, Vairo F et al. Neuroimaging Findings in Patients with Mucopolysaccharidosis: What You Really Need to Know. Radiographics. 2016;36 (5): 1448-62.
  4. Resnick DL. Diagnosis of bone and joint disorders. Saunders. 2002.

data.title: PERMACATH
data.content:
The catheter shown in the image is a Central Tunneled Long-Term Hemodialysis Catheter, often referred to as a Permacath. This type of catheter is designed for long-term use in hemodialysis patients.

Key Features

  1. Dual Lumen: The catheter has two ports (usually color-coded red and blue) which are utilized for different flow directions. The red port typically functions for arterial access (outflow of blood), while the blue port is for venous return (inflow).

  2. Different Port Lengths: The ports vary in length, allowing different flow rates, which makes this catheter adaptable to patient-specific requirements.

  3. Tunneled Design: It is surgically tunneled under the skin, which provides enhanced stability and minimizes infection risks compared to non-tunneled catheters.

Indications

  1. Chronic Hemodialysis: Primarily for patients needing long-term dialysis, especially when AV fistulas or grafts are unavailable or not feasible.
  2. Acute Renal Failure with Prolonged Dialysis Requirement: Can be used when prolonged dialysis is anticipated, though kidney recovery is expected eventually.
  3. Bridge to Permanent Access: Used temporarily until a more permanent vascular access, such as a fistula or graft, can be established.
  4. No Other Vascular Access Options: Ideal for patients who have limited vascular access alternatives.

Types and Variants

  1. Cuffed vs. Non-Cuffed: Cuffed catheters offer better infection control and stability, whereas non-cuffed ones are for shorter-term use.
  2. Split vs. Coaxial Lumen:
    • Split lumen has two distinct channels for inflow and outflow.
    • Coaxial lumen includes one inner lumen inside an outer lumen, enhancing flow rates.
  3. Single vs. Dual Lumen: Dual-lumen designs are more common in hemodialysis, allowing simultaneous withdrawal and return of blood.

Additional Uses

Apart from hemodialysis, these catheters may be used in:

  • Medication Administration: In cases where alternative access points are unavailable.
  • Plasmapheresis or Apheresis Procedures: Utilized for high-flow-rate procedures like plasma exchange.

data.title: Percutaneous Nephrostomy Set
data.content:
Introduction

Percutaneous nephrostomy provides minimally invasive renal access via a catheter, typically under imaging guidance, for urinary diversion, decompression, or other renal interventions.

Indications

  • Urinary Obstruction: Provides decompression for obstructed uropathy.
  • Urinary Diversion: Useful in ureteric injuries or urine leaks.
  • Access for Procedures: Ideal for stone treatment or antegrade stent placement.
  • Diagnostics: Applied in tests like antegrade pyelography or the Whitaker test.

Contraindications

  • Relative Contraindications: Unmanageable bleeding disorders, severe respiratory disease, uncooperative patients, or uncorrected severe metabolic disturbances (hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis).

Procedure Protocol

  1. Preparation: Confirm indication and access via imaging, check coagulation profile, secure IV access, and administer antibiotics if needed.
  2. Positioning: Patient in prone, prone oblique, or lateral position with continuous vital monitoring.
  3. Equipment: Imaging (ultrasound/fluoroscopy), local anesthesia (1% or 2% lidocaine), 18-gauge needle (or 21–22 gauge for micropuncture), guidewire (0.035 inches), dilators (7–9 French), and pigtail drain (usually 8 French).
  4. Technique: Under sterile conditions, a posterior calyx is accessed with the needle, confirmed with urine drainage and contrast under fluoroscopy. An 8 French pigtail drain is placed for free drainage.

Post-Procedure Care

  • Bed Rest: Typically 2–4 hours with vital monitoring and fluid assessment.
  • Nephrostomy Exchange: Catheters are replaced every three months.
  • Patient Caution: Care should be taken to avoid tube dislodgement.

Complications

  • Bleeding, pneumothorax, bowel injury, urine leak, and catheter blockage/dislodgement (~20% incidence within months).

A Glimpse into History

"Imagine 1955, jukeboxes and the birth of percutaneous nephrostomy! Dr. Goodwin and team thought, ‘Let’s go right through the back for kidney access!’ And the rest is history—a kidney revolution, even if explaining it back then must’ve been a wild ride."

data.title: Tubular ectasia of the rete testis
data.content:
The ultrasound scan of the testis showing features consistent with tubular ectasia of the rete testis. This condition is characterized by the presence of multiple small anechoic or cystic structures within the testicular mediastinum, typically without significant mass effect or vascularity, distinguishing it from more malignant conditions.

 

Overview:

Tubular Ectasia of the Rete Testis is a benign condition involving dilated testicular mediastinal tubules, often observed in men older than 55 years. It is frequently asymptomatic and incidentally discovered during imaging studies.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Commonly associated with age (seen more frequently in men over 55).
  • Often related to spermatoceles or following vasectomy.
  • Partial or complete obliteration of efferent ducts is considered the underlying cause.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Rete Testis: A network of tubules located in the mediastinum testis, connecting the seminiferous tubules to the efferent ducts.
  • The condition involves dilated tubules in this area, seen as multiple small cystic or tubular structures.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

  • Tubular ectasia is thought to result from obstruction of the efferent ducts leading to dilatation of the rete testis. This results in the formation of small, cyst-like structures, which are filled with sperm and may communicate with the epididymis.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Asymptomatic: Most cases are detected incidentally during imaging for unrelated reasons.
  • Rarely, patients may present with a palpable lump or swelling in the scrotum.

 

Classification:

  • Classified based on whether the condition is unilateral or bilateral.
  • Often occurs bilaterally, particularly when associated with vasectomy or other pathologies like spermatoceles.

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Ultrasound is the key imaging modality to identify and confirm the diagnosis.
  • Complication Assessment: Rule out potential complications like cyst formation or secondary infections.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: While typically benign, monitoring can be done in cases where patients present with symptoms or associated conditions.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Ultrasound: Appears as multiple small, anechoic or cystic structures, primarily within the testicular mediastinum. There is no mass effect or significant vascularity on Doppler imaging.
  • MRI: On T2-weighted imaging, tubular ectasia appears as hyperintense dilated tubules. No internal enhancement is observed with contrast.

 

Management:

  • No treatment required unless there are associated symptoms or complications. The condition is benign and usually does not progress.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  1. Intratesticular Varicocele: Differs in that it demonstrates flow on color Doppler.
  2. Cystadenoma of the Rete Testis: Unlike tubular ectasia, this is a neoplastic process and may show different features on imaging.
  3. Epididymal Cysts: May be confused with tubular ectasia but are located in the epididymis rather than the testis.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Kim W, Rosen MA, Langer JE et al. US MR Imaging Correlation in Pathologic Conditions of the Scrotum. Radiographics.
  2. Ishigami K, Abu-Yousef MM, El-Zein Y. Tubular Ectasia of the Epididymis: A Sign of Postvasectomy Status. J Clin Ultrasound.
  3. Nair R, Abbaraju J, Rajbabu K, Anjum F, Sriprasad S. Tubular Ectasia of the Rete Testis: A Diagnostic Dilemma.

data.title: Arrowhead sign
data.content:
The CT scan image shows focal cecal thickening at the appendiceal orifice, highlighted by the arrows, consistent with the arrowhead sign of acute appendicitis. The contrast material in the cecal lumen forms an arrowhead-like shape pointing towards the appendix, a key indicator of inflammation in the cecal region surrounding the appendix.

 

Overview:

The arrowhead sign is a radiological indicator of acute appendicitis, seen on CT imaging as a focal thickening of the cecum around the appendiceal orifice. This sign is identified when contrast material within the cecum assumes an arrowhead-like configuration pointing toward the inflamed appendix.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Appendicitis: Inflammation of the appendix.
  • Obstruction: Fecalith or other obstruction in the appendiceal lumen.
  • Infection: Can lead to acute inflammation of the appendix.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Cecum: The most proximal part of the large intestine, where the appendix arises.
  • Appendiceal Orifice: The entry point of the appendix into the cecum.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

In acute appendicitis, inflammation and obstruction of the appendix cause localized edema and focal thickening of the cecal wall near the appendiceal orifice. The contrast in the cecal lumen accentuates this thickening, resulting in the arrowhead configuration.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Right lower quadrant pain (often localized at McBurney's point).
  • Fever and elevated white blood cell count.
  • Nausea, vomiting, and decreased appetite.

 

Classification:

  • Uncomplicated appendicitis: Early stages without perforation.
  • Complicated appendicitis: Appendiceal rupture, abscess, or peritonitis.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Detect appendicitis and localize the inflammation.
  • Complication Assessment: Identify complications such as perforation or abscess formation.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Monitor post-treatment recovery or recurrent episodes.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • CT Scan:
    • Arrowhead sign: Focal thickening in the cecum pointing toward the appendix.
    • Peri-appendiceal fat stranding and localized inflammation.
    • Appendiceal wall thickening and potential abscess or phlegmon in complicated cases.
  • Ultrasound:
    • Target or bullseye sign with a thickened, non-compressible appendix.
    • Free fluid may be seen in complicated cases.

 

Complications:

  • Perforation: Rupture of the appendix leading to peritonitis.
  • Abscess formation: Collection of pus due to localized infection.
  • Sepsis: Systemic infection in severe or untreated cases.

 

Management:

Management typically involves surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy) or antibiotic therapy in select non-surgical cases.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Cecal diverticulitis: Inflammation of a diverticulum in the cecum.
  • Crohn’s disease: Inflammatory bowel disease involving the terminal ileum.
  • Mesenteric adenitis: Inflammation of mesenteric lymph nodes.
  • Ovarian pathology: In females, ovarian torsion or rupture can mimic appendicitis symptoms.

 

A Glimpse of History:

The arrowhead sign was described as an important secondary sign of appendicitis in patients undergoing CT scans with enteric contrast. It helps radiologists accurately identify the appendiceal orifice as the origin of cecal inflammation, guiding appropriate management.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Pinto Leite N, Pereira JM, Cunha R et al. CT evaluation of appendicitis and its complications: imaging techniques and key diagnostic findings. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2005;185 (2): 406-17.
  2. Weissleder R, Wittenberg J, Harisinghani MG. Primer of Diagnostic Imaging. Mosby Inc. (2003).

data.title: Kirklin sign
data.content:
The chest X-ray demonstrates an abnormality in the region of the gastric bubble, marked by an arrow, consistent with Kirklin sign. The image shows a deformity in the gastric bubble, which typically appears as a smooth, rounded air-filled structure in the left upper quadrant. In the case of Kirklin sign, this deformity suggests the presence of a mass in the gastric cardia or fundus.

 

Overview:

Kirklin sign refers to the deformation or abnormal contour of the gastric bubble seen on an upright chest X-ray, indicating the presence of a mass in the gastric cardia or fundus.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Gastric tumors: Most commonly adenocarcinoma or gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
  • Esophageal carcinoma: A tumor involving the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Gastro-esophageal varices: Can cause local mass effect.
  • Fundoplication surgery: Postoperative changes can deform the gastric bubble.
  • Other Gastroesophageal Tumors: Including lymphoma.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Gastric Cardia: The region of the stomach adjacent to the esophagus, where a tumor could deform the bubble.
  • Gastric Fundus: The upper part of the stomach, where tumors or masses may present and affect the normal air-filled gastric bubble on a radiograph.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

A mass lesion (tumor, varices, or surgical alteration) in the gastric cardia or fundus distorts the normal outline of the gastric bubble seen on an upright chest radiograph. This mass effect alters the typical curvature and volume of the air-filled space.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing, commonly associated with gastroesophageal tumors.
  • Abdominal pain: Particularly in the upper left quadrant.
  • Weight loss: A common feature of malignancy such as gastric carcinoma.
  • Hematemesis: Vomiting of blood in advanced cases involving ulcers or varices.

 

Classification:

  • Simple Kirklin Sign: Deformity of the gastric bubble without other notable findings.
  • Complex Kirklin Sign (Kirklin Complex): Includes additional radiographic findings on fluoroscopy such as upper GI obstruction or involvement of surrounding structures.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Detection of gastric or gastroesophageal lesions by observing abnormal contours of the gastric bubble on chest X-ray.
  • Complication Assessment: Identifying associated conditions like perforation or obstruction.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Monitoring the progression of the lesion or post-surgical changes.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Chest Radiograph:
    • Deformed or absent gastric bubble in the left upper quadrant.
    • Mass effect in the region of the gastric cardia or fundus.
  • Fluoroscopy (Upper GI series):
    • More detailed examination of the gastric cardia and fundus.
    • Helps differentiate between mechanical obstruction and mass effect.
  • CT Scan:
    • Provides a detailed evaluation of mass lesions in the gastroesophageal region.
    • Useful in staging malignancies and evaluating lymph node involvement.

 

Complications:

  • Obstruction: A large mass may obstruct the gastric outlet or esophagus.
  • Hemorrhage: Especially with gastric carcinoma or varices.
  • Perforation: Tumor invasion may cause rupture of the gastric or esophageal wall.
  • Malnutrition: Progressive difficulty in eating due to dysphagia or obstruction.

 

Management:

Management typically involves surgical resection or chemotherapy/radiotherapy for malignancies, and endoscopic interventions for benign conditions like varices or post-fundoplication complications.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Schatzki Ring: A circumferential narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Hiatal Hernia: Gastric fundus protruding through the diaphragm, distorting the gastric bubble.
  • Achalasia: Functional esophageal disorder causing esophageal dilation and possible bubble deformation.
  • Varices: Enlarged veins can create a mass effect, altering the gastric bubble contour.

 

 A Glimpse of the History:

Kirklin sign was named after Dr. Byrl Raymond Kirklin, an American radiologist, who described this finding in a 1939 publication. Kirklin was a pioneer in identifying radiological signs of gastric and esophageal pathologies through fluoroscopic and radiographic techniques.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Kirklin BR. Roentgenologic diagnosis of cancer of the cardia. AJR 1939; 41:873-880.
  2. Gurney JW, Olson DL, Schroeder BA. The gastric bubble: roentgen observations. Radiographics. 1989;9 (3): 467-85.
  3. Jenkinson EL. Byrl Raymond Kirklin, M.D., 1888–1957. Radiology 1957;68:877-878.

data.title: Esophageal web
data.content:
The image demonstrates an esophageal web on a barium swallow study. An esophageal web appears as a thin membranous constriction projecting into the lumen of the esophagus, leading to narrowing. The image shows a clear indentation in the barium column, with a web-like structure causing partial obstruction of the esophagus.

 

Overview:

Esophageal webs are thin membranous projections of the mucosa into the esophageal lumen, most often found in the cervical esophagus. They cause constriction but do not extend through the entire esophageal wall, and are often asymptomatic.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: Commonly associated with esophageal webs and iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Especially in cases with distal esophageal webs.
  • Graft-Versus-Host Disease: Patients with a history of bone marrow transplant may develop webs.
  • External Beam Radiation: Esophageal webs can develop after radiation exposure.
  • Esophageal Candidiasis: Infection can predispose patients to esophageal webs.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Cervical Esophagus: The most common location for esophageal webs, often near the cricopharyngeus muscle.
  • Anterior Wall: Webs most commonly arise from the anterior esophageal wall.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

Esophageal webs are formed by the mucosal layer of the esophagus projecting into the lumen, causing narrowing. This can result from chronic inflammation (e.g., GERD or candidiasis), congenital factors, or secondary causes such as iron deficiency.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing is the most common symptom, especially for solids.
  • Regurgitation: Food may regurgitate due to partial obstruction.
  • Asymptomatic: Many patients remain asymptomatic, and the web is detected incidentally.

 

Classification:

  • Single Web: Typically, only one web is present.
  • Multiple Webs: Less common but can be seen, particularly in severe cases.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: A barium swallow study is the best initial imaging modality for diagnosing esophageal webs.
  • Complication Assessment: Evaluate for associated conditions such as strictures, reflux, or carcinoma.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Serial imaging may be necessary for patients with recurrent symptoms or after treatment.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Barium Swallow (Fluoroscopy):
    • Appears as a thin, shelf-like constriction of the esophagus.
    • May be seen during maximal distention of the esophagus.
    • “Jet effect” can be seen where contrast passes distal to the web.
  • Endoscopy:
    • Can directly visualize the web and confirm the diagnosis.
    • Webs may appear thin and membranous, sometimes circumferential.

 

Complications:

  • Dysphagia: Persistent dysphagia may worsen with time.
  • Carcinoma Risk: Patients with esophageal webs, particularly in association with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, have an increased risk of developing upper esophageal or hypopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Strictures: In some cases, webs may lead to the formation of esophageal strictures.

 

Management:

Treatment options include balloon dilation or bougienage during endoscopy to relieve the obstruction caused by the web.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Schatzki Ring: A circumferential narrowing seen in the distal esophagus, often confused with webs.
  • Submucosal Venous Plexus: Normal anatomical structures that can sometimes mimic webs on imaging.
  • Esophageal Stricture: Webs may be associated with strictures or mimic their presentation.

A Glimpse of the History:

Esophageal webs have been known for many years and are particularly associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome. They were originally described in relation to dysphagia and iron-deficiency anemia in middle-aged women.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Karasick S, Lev-toaff AS. Esophageal strictures: findings on barium radiographs. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 1995;165 (3): 561-5.
  2. Rees CJ, Belafsky PC. Upper esophageal web. Ear Nose Throat J. 2007;86 (12): 732.
  3. Kim KH, Kim MC, Jung GJ. Gastric cancer occurring in a patient with Plummer-Vinson syndrome: a case report. World J. Gastroenterol. 2005;11 (44): 7048-50.
  4. Eisenberg RL. Gastrointestinal radiology. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. (2003).
  5. Taylor AJ, Stewart ET, Dodds WJ. The esophageal "jet" phenomenon revisited. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 1990;155 (2): 289-90.

data.title: Esophageal pseudodiverticulosis
data.content:
The image shows a barium swallow study demonstrating esophageal pseudodiverticulosis. This condition presents as numerous small, flask-shaped outpouchings (pseudodiverticula) seen within the esophageal wall, appearing as small outpouchings on the barium study. These are typically diffusely distributed along the esophagus.

 

Overview:

Esophageal pseudodiverticulosis refers to the presence of multiple small outpouchings of the esophageal wall, representing dilated excretory ducts of the deep esophageal mucosal glands. It is a rare condition, found in less than 1% of esophagograms.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Esophageal Strictures: Seen in 90% of patients with esophageal pseudodiverticulosis.
  • Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): Chronic irritation of the esophagus can lead to the development of pseudodiverticula.
  • Esophageal Candidiasis: Infection can predispose patients to pseudodiverticulosis.
  • Chronic Esophagitis: Chronic inflammation leads to dilated esophageal gland ducts.
  • Esophageal Carcinoma: Malignant processes may coexist or lead to the formation of pseudodiverticula.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Esophagus: The small outpouchings are seen within the esophageal wall, representing dilated ducts from esophageal glands.
  • Intramural Location: Pseudodiverticula originate from the esophageal submucosa and do not penetrate through the full thickness of the esophageal wall.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

The pseudodiverticula represent dilated excretory ducts of the deep mucosal glands. Chronic irritation or inflammation, such as from reflux or infection, causes the ducts to dilate. These small outpouchings appear as tiny flask-shaped projections from the esophageal wall.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing is the most common presenting symptom due to associated esophageal strictures.
  • Chest Pain: Occasionally reported in cases of severe esophageal involvement.
  • Regurgitation: Food may regurgitate due to poor esophageal motility in affected segments.
  • Infection: Esophageal candidiasis or other infections can complicate the condition.

 

Classification:

  • Diffuse Esophageal Pseudodiverticulosis: Involves widespread distribution of pseudodiverticula throughout the esophagus.
  • Segmental Esophageal Pseudodiverticulosis: Localized to a specific region of the esophagus, often associated with strictures.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: A barium swallow study is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice for esophageal pseudodiverticulosis.
  • Complication Assessment: Look for strictures, candidiasis, or even rare rupture with mediastinitis.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Endoscopic and imaging surveillance can help monitor for complications such as worsening strictures or the development of carcinoma.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Fluoroscopy (Barium Swallow):
    • Small (1-4 mm), flask-shaped outpouchings seen on the esophageal wall.
    • Outpouchings may appear clustered near strictures.
    • Single-contrast barium study better delineates these pseudodiverticula.
  • CT:
    • Can show thickening of the esophageal wall with small intramural gas collections.
    • May demonstrate associated esophageal strictures or infections.
  • Endoscopy:
    • Difficult to visualize pseudodiverticula directly due to their small size, but can reveal associated conditions like esophagitis or strictures.

 

Complications:

  • Esophageal Strictures: Narrowing of the esophagus, often requiring dilation.
  • Esophageal Perforation: Rare but can occur if the pseudodiverticula rupture, leading to mediastinitis.
  • Recurrent Infections: Particularly in cases associated with esophageal candidiasis.
  • Esophageal Carcinoma: Can develop in chronic cases, requiring close monitoring.

 

Management:

Management includes treating the underlying condition (e.g., GERD or infection), dilation of strictures, and proton pump inhibitors to relieve esophagitis.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Esophageal Diverticula: Full-thickness diverticula, larger in size and extending through the muscular layer.
  • Esophageal Candidiasis: Can coexist with pseudodiverticulosis and cause similar dysphagia.
  • Esophageal Carcinoma: May cause strictures and need to be ruled out, especially if there is no improvement with treatment.
  • Peptic Strictures: May present similarly, but without the characteristic pseudodiverticula.

 

A Glimpse of History:

Esophageal pseudodiverticulosis was first described as a rare entity in the mid-20th century and is associated with various underlying esophageal conditions. Its recognition is important as it can mimic other more serious conditions like carcinoma.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Levine MS, Moolten DN, Herlinger H et al. Esophageal intramural pseudodiverticulosis: a reevaluation. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 1986;147 (6): 1165-70.
  2. Canon CL, Levine MS, Cherukuri R et al. Intramural tracking: a feature of esophageal intramural pseudodiverticulosis. AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2000;175 (2): 371-4.
  3. Weissleder R, Wittenberg J, Harisinghani MG. Primer of diagnostic imaging. Mosby Inc. (2003).

data.title: Frostberg-inverted 3 sign
data.content:
The image shows a barium study with the Frostberg inverted 3 sign. This sign is a classic radiological finding where there is distortion of the mucosal pattern on the medial wall of the second part of the duodenum. The effacement appears as an inverted “3” or “E” shape, which is usually due to mass effect from an underlying lesion such as a carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

 

Overview:

Frostberg inverted 3 sign is a barium study finding, predominantly seen in cases of pancreatic head carcinoma, but can also be observed in other pathologies affecting the periampullary region, such as duodenal carcinoma or pancreatitis.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Pancreatic Head Carcinoma: Most common cause, leading to extrinsic compression of the second part of the duodenum.
  • Duodenal Carcinoma: Direct involvement or compression of the duodenum.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis: Can cause localized inflammatory changes, leading to mucosal distortion.
  • Periampullary Lesions: Tumors or other pathologies affecting the duodenal ampullary region.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Second Part of the Duodenum: The medial wall of the descending duodenum is compressed, causing distortion of the mucosal folds.
  • Head of the Pancreas: Tumors or lesions here can exert pressure on the surrounding structures, including the duodenum, resulting in the inverted “3” shape.
  • Ampulla of Vater: Can be involved in the process, particularly in periampullary tumors.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

In pancreatic head carcinoma, the growing mass in the head of the pancreas exerts extrinsic pressure on the adjacent second part of the duodenum, leading to distortion of the mucosa. This pressure causes the characteristic "inverted 3" sign as the mucosal folds are effaced and reshaped.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Jaundice: Due to obstruction of the bile duct by pancreatic masses.
  • Weight Loss: Common in pancreatic cancer.
  • Epigastric Pain: Due to local invasion or mass effect.
  • Nausea and Vomiting: In cases with duodenal obstruction.
  • Steatorrhea: Malabsorption from biliary obstruction.

 

Classification:

The Frostberg inverted 3 sign is primarily seen in:

  1. Pancreatic Head Carcinoma
  2. Duodenal Carcinoma
  3. Chronic Pancreatitis (less commonly)
  4. Periampullary Tumors

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: To confirm the presence of duodenal compression and identify potential underlying masses or lesions.
  • Complication Assessment: Can evaluate for associated complications like biliary obstruction or duodenal obstruction.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: To monitor response to treatment or progression of the lesion.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Barium Study (Fluoroscopy):
    • Shows the inverted “3” or “E” sign in the second part of the duodenum.
    • There may be associated narrowing of the lumen.
  • CT/MRI:
    • Can identify the primary lesion causing the distortion (e.g., pancreatic head mass).
    • Evaluate for lymphadenopathy, biliary dilation, and local invasion.
  • Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS):
    • Can be useful for detailed evaluation of periampullary masses and bile duct involvement.

 

Complications:

  • Biliary Obstruction: Leading to jaundice and cholangitis.
  • Duodenal Obstruction: Causing nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
  • Local Invasion: In cases of malignancy, spread to nearby structures can occur.
  • Pancreatitis: If the pancreatic duct is involved.

 

Management:

Management often involves surgical resection of the underlying mass if operable, or palliative treatment, including biliary stenting for relief of obstruction.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Duodenal Carcinoma: Can present similarly with mucosal distortion.
  • Periampullary Tumors: May also cause effacement of the duodenal mucosa.
  • Chronic Pancreatitis: Can sometimes mimic this appearance, though less common.
  • Peptic Ulcer Disease: Rarely causes similar mucosal changes but should be considered.

 

A Glimpse of History:

The Frostberg inverted 3 sign was first described by Dr. Nils Frostberg, a Swedish radiologist, in 1938. His work identified this characteristic duodenal deformity caused by periampullary masses, especially pancreatic carcinoma, which continues to be an important diagnostic clue in gastrointestinal radiology.

 

Bibliography:

  1. Frostberg N. A Characteristic Duodenal Deformity in Cases of Different Kinds of Peri-Vaterial Enlargement of the Pancreas. Acta Radiol. 1938;19(2):164-73. doi:10.3109/

data.title: Caroli disease
data.content:
The CT image demonstrates classic findings of Caroli disease. This includes the cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts with the “central dot sign,” where enhancing portal radicles are seen within the dilated bile ducts. This appearance is highly suggestive of Caroli disease and represents the dilated biliary system surrounding the portal vein radicles.

 

Overview:

Caroli disease is a rare congenital disorder characterized by the saccular or fusiform dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts. When associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis, it is referred to as Caroli syndrome. It is classified under Todani classification as type V choledochal cyst.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Autosomal Recessive Inheritance: Primarily associated with a defect in the PKHD1 gene, which is also linked to autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD).
  • Congenital Malformation of the Ductal Plate: Results from the abnormal development of large intrahepatic bile ducts in utero.
  • Renal Associations: Caroli disease is frequently associated with medullary sponge kidney and ARPKD.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Intrahepatic Bile Ducts: Show diffuse, segmental, or lobar cystic dilatation.
  • Portal Radicles: Appear as “central dots” surrounded by dilated bile ducts.
  • Liver Parenchyma: May be affected by secondary changes like cirrhosis in Caroli syndrome.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

Caroli disease arises from a developmental anomaly of the ductal plate during fetal development. The dilated bile ducts accumulate bile, which may lead to stasis, infection, and stone formation, while in Caroli syndrome, fibrosis develops around the smaller bile ducts leading to portal hypertension.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Right Upper Quadrant Pain
  • Recurrent Biliary Infections: Leading to cholangitis.
  • Cholelithiasis: Formation of bile stones due to stasis.
  • Portal Hypertension: Seen in Caroli syndrome, with complications like variceal bleeding and ascites.
  • Jaundice: Due to recurrent obstruction and infection.

 

Classification:

  1. Type I Caroli Disease (Simple Type): Characterized by isolated cystic dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts.
  2. Type II Caroli Disease (Caroli Syndrome): A combination of cystic dilatation and congenital hepatic fibrosis, often leading to portal hypertension.

 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Helps confirm the diagnosis by visualizing dilated bile ducts and assess the presence of complications such as cholangitis or portal hypertension.
  • Complication Assessment: Identifies biliary stones, cholangitis, and liver fibrosis.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Monitor for the development of complications such as cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Ultrasound: Shows multiple dilated intrahepatic ducts, with possible intraductal calculi. Echogenic septa can sometimes traverse the dilated bile ducts.
  • CT:
    • Hypodense areas representing dilated bile ducts.
    • “Central dot sign”: Enhancing portal radicles within the dilated ducts.
  • MRI:
    • T1: Hypointense dilatation.
    • T2: Hyperintense cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts.
    • MRCP: Useful in demonstrating communication of dilated ducts with the biliary tree.
  • Nuclear Medicine: May demonstrate the beaded appearance of the bile ducts on HIDA scans.

 

Complications:

  • Biliary Stones: Formation due to bile stasis.
  • Recurrent Cholangitis: Leading to sepsis.
  • Portal Hypertension: Particularly in Caroli syndrome.
  • Increased Risk of Cholangiocarcinoma: Risk is increased by 10%, especially in Caroli syndrome.

 

Management:

Management includes treating complications like cholangitis and cholestasis. Surgical resection may be offered for localized disease, while liver transplantation is considered for diffuse disease with complications.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Polycystic Liver Disease: Does not involve bile duct dilation.
  • Peribiliary Cysts: Cysts located around the bile ducts but do not communicate with them.
  • Choledochal Cyst: A broader category of biliary cystic disorders.
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis: Presents with bile duct strictures and dilatation, often more fusiform than saccular.
  • Recurrent Pyogenic Cholangitis: Infection-related biliary dilation, often associated with stones.

 

A Glimpse of History:

Caroli disease is named after Jacques Caroli, a French gastroenterologist who first described the condition in 1958. His work brought attention to this rare congenital disorder that shares genetic and developmental origins with polycystic kidney diseases.

data.title: infantile hepatic hemangiomas
data.content:
CT scan of the liver in a pediatric patient, showing multiple spherical lesions that resemble cystic masses with septations. This is typical of infantile hepatic hemangiomas, which are composed of large, endothelial-lined vascular channels. These are the most common benign liver masses in pediatric patients, usually occurring within the first six months of life.

 

Overview:

Infantile Hepatic Hemangioma (IHH) is a benign vascular tumor seen in neonates and infants, particularly during the first few months of life. It is characterized by abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the liver, similar to hemangiomas in other parts of the body.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Congenital vascular malformation: Developmental anomalies lead to abnormal blood vessel formation.
  • Hypothyroidism: High levels of type 3-iodothyronine deiodinase activity produced by hemangiomas can lead to hypothyroidism.
  • Associations: It is often associated with other hemangiomas on the skin or in other organs (10% of cases).

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Liver: The liver parenchyma is replaced or infiltrated by multiple vascular channels and cyst-like structures.
  • Hepatic Arteries: Hypertrophy of the hepatic artery and celiac trunk can be seen due to the vascular nature of the lesion.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

Infantile hepatic hemangiomas are composed of blood vessels that are abnormal and proliferate within the liver. These vascular channels may lead to high-output heart failure, as blood is shunted through the lesion instead of properly circulating through the systemic circulation.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Hepatomegaly: The liver may be enlarged due to the size of the hemangiomas.
  • Congestive Heart Failure: Due to high-output cardiac failure caused by arteriovenous shunting within the lesion.
  • Respiratory Distress: Neonates can present with respiratory difficulties due to the large size of the lesion.
  • Kasabach-Merritt Sequence: This can occur, presenting with thrombocytopenia and consumptive coagulopathy.

 

Classification:

  • Focal: Localized to a single area of the liver.
  • Multifocal: Multiple lesions distributed throughout the liver (as seen in the current image).
  • Diffuse: Entire liver involvement with a more widespread infiltration of the parenchyma.


 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Ultrasound or CT is typically used to diagnose and assess the extent of the lesion.
  • Complication Assessment: Imaging helps evaluate the presence of complications like high-output heart failure or Kasabach-Merritt sequence.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Serial imaging is used to monitor the involution of the hemangiomas or response to medical therapy.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Ultrasound: Hypoechoic, hyperechoic, or mixed echogenicity with prominent vascular channels. Increased flow on color Doppler.
  • CT: Shows peripheral enhancement with gradual filling-in, characteristic of hemangiomas. Aortic caliber may be reduced due to vascular distribution to the liver. The lesions may have a Swiss cheese appearance due to septations and cystic spaces.
  • MRI: Shows T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense signals due to the vascular nature of the tumor. The lesions enhance uniformly with contrast, showing vascular flow voids.

 

Complications:

  • Cardiac Failure: Due to arteriovenous shunting in large or multiple lesions.
  • Hemolytic Anemia: May occur due to vascular compromise.
  • Respiratory Distress: Especially in cases with hepatomegaly pressing against the diaphragm.
  • Kasabach-Merritt Sequence: Consumptive coagulopathy leading to thrombocytopenia.

 

Management:

  • Observation: In asymptomatic patients, the lesion is allowed to regress spontaneously.
  • Propranolol: This is the first-line treatment for symptomatic patients with high-output cardiac failure.
  • Embolization: In cases where medical management fails, embolization can be performed to control the arteriovenous shunting.
  • Surgery: Rarely required but may be performed for very large lesions causing significant mass effect or complications.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Hepatoblastoma: A malignant liver tumor, often associated with elevated AFP levels.
  • Neuroblastoma Metastasis: Multiple liver lesions are seen, often in older children.
  • Mesenchymal Hamartoma: Usually presents as a multilocular cystic mass, though often larger and more septated.
  • Hepatic Abscess: Usually presents with systemic infection signs and a different imaging appearance.

 

A Glimpse of History:

Infantile hepatic hemangiomas were previously termed hepatic infantile hemangioendotheliomas but have been reclassified as hemangiomas due to their similarity with other hemangiomas in the body. The history of their management has evolved with the use of propranolol, which significantly improved outcomes for symptomatic patients.

  3. Kassarjian A, Zurakowski D, Dubois J et-al. Clinical and imaging findings of infantile hepatic hemangiomas.

data.title: Hepatic mesenchymal hamartoma
data.content:
This is a CT scan showing a large cystic lesion within the liver, consistent with the typical imaging appearance of a hepatic mesenchymal hamartoma. The lesion is multiseptated, predominantly cystic with some possible solid components, which are characteristic findings on CT for this benign tumor.

 

Overview:

Hepatic Mesenchymal Hamartoma is a rare, benign tumor that primarily affects young children and infants. It is considered to be a developmental anomaly rather than a true neoplasm and is composed of abnormal mixtures of liver tissue elements like bile ducts, blood vessels, and loose connective tissue.

 

Cause and Predisposing Factors:

  • Congenital anomaly: It is thought to arise from abnormal development during fetal growth.
  • Genetic factors: Abnormal expression of the chromosome 19 microRNA cluster or mutations in the DICER1 gene have been linked to mesenchymal hamartomas.
  • Age: Primarily affects children under 2 years of age.

 

Pertinent Radiological Anatomy:

  • Liver: The hamartoma affects the liver, often in the right lobe.
  • Portal Vein and Hepatic Arteries: While the lesion itself is not typically vascular, it may compress or distort surrounding vascular structures.

 

Mechanism of Disease:

The tumor is composed of an admixture of ductal structures, blood vessels, and connective tissue. The mesenchymal components, which make up the bulk of the lesion, can grow into large cystic masses, causing mass effect on nearby organs and possibly leading to abdominal distension and respiratory distress.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Abdominal distension: Due to the large size of the tumor.
  • Respiratory distress: In cases where the mass becomes large enough to exert pressure on the diaphragm.
  • Normal alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are common, though rare cases may present with elevated AFP.

 

Classification:

  • Cystic: The most common form, appearing as large multiseptated cysts.
  • Solid/Cystic: A mixture of solid and cystic components.
  • Predominantly solid: Less common, these lesions may mimic more aggressive tumors on imaging.


 

Imaging Role:

  • Preliminary Evaluation: Ultrasound or CT is used for initial diagnosis.
  • Complication Assessment: Large lesions can cause complications, and imaging helps assess for compression of nearby structures.
  • Surveillance and Follow-Up: Post-surgical imaging ensures that there is no recurrence of the lesion.

 

Imaging Characteristics in Different Modalities:

  • Ultrasound: Appears as a multiseptated cystic lesion with some solid components. Pedunculated lesions may be challenging to detect.
  • CT: Shows a heterogeneous mass with cystic and solid portions. The cystic areas usually have water-like attenuation, while the solid portions show heterogeneous enhancement after contrast.
  • MRI: Cystic components are predominant, and the appearance varies depending on the presence of stromal elements and the protein content of the cyst fluid.
  • Plain Radiograph: May show a large, non-calcified mass in the right upper quadrant but is usually nonspecific.

 

Complications:

  • Fetal Hydrops: Occurs in prenatal cases, due to mass effect.
  • Respiratory Distress: Due to pressure on the diaphragm from the large abdominal mass.
  • Circulatory Complications: Large lesions may compress surrounding vessels, causing circulatory compromise.

 

Management:

The primary treatment is surgical resection, which is curative. In some cases, ultrasound-guided aspiration of cystic components can be done to reduce tumor size and facilitate resection.

 

Alternative Diagnosis:

  • Hepatic Abscess: Differentiated by clinical symptoms and imaging features such as septations and fluid collections.
  • Hepatoblastoma: A malignant liver tumor in children, often associated with elevated AFP and predominance of solid components.
  • Undifferentiated Sarcoma: Rare malignant tumors in older children, typically more solid and aggressive on imaging.
  • Infantile Hemangioendothelioma: A vascular tumor with associations like midaortic syndrome, often seen in the liver of infants.

A Glimpse of History:

Hepatic mesenchymal hamartomas were initially thought to be cystic neoplasms but have since been reclassified as developmental anomalies. Recent advancements in genetic research have linked these tumors to mutations in the DICER1 gene and abnormalities in microRNA expression on chromosome 19.
